unit_learning_outcomes.description: Use a sophisticated analytical vocabulary for better appreciating the most pressing contemporary issues in Australian politics
Communicate the key features of Australia's main political institutions and the debates and controversies that surround them
Demonstrate familiarity with the main political ideologies and parties that are influential in the Australia political scene
Articulate a sound understanding of the foundations of the Australian political system and its relationship to its global context

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Do all set readings in preparation for lectures and online participation

assessments.description: The final, two-hour online exam will require students to write three short essays, drawn from topics across the entire unit.
There will be one online quiz in week 4 of the unit.
This is a 1500-word essay +/- 10%, with topics drawn from across the unit, which allows students to explore a research topic in depth

The emphasis will be on students engaging with both the week's topics and other students' contributions to exploring contemporary issues in Australian politics. Students will be assessed on the quality of their contributions.

data.subject_search_title: POIX1010 - Australian Politics in Global Context
data.description: In this unit, we critically assess Australian politics from the perspective of political and economic history, through the lens of social power and financial interests, and drilling down into contemporary debates about economic crisis, globalisation, nationalism, environmental catastrophe and war. With this approach in mind, we examine key Australian political institutions, ideologies, and issues. What is the nature of Australia's key political institutions (the Constitution, the High Court, Federalism, Government and Parliament), and are they democratic and just? Could we live without them? What are some of the radical critiques of these institutions and the interests they serve? What is 'Australia', after all - a unified nation of peoples with shared identities and interests, or a construct that serves wealth and power by masking deep social fractures, or something else again?
